<p><strong>As the coronavirus pandemic spreads</strong> across the globe, threatening both <a href="/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/safeguarding-our-lives-and-our-livelihoods-the-imperative-of-our-time">lives and livelihoods</a>, consumer-packaged-goods (CPG) manufacturers continue to play an important role: producing essential items we all rely on for our health and well-being. CPG leaders have focused on meeting this demand while guarding the safety of employees and customers.</p>
<p>At the same time, forward-thinking CPG companies have begun to think about the “<a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/beyond-coronavirus-the-path-to-the-next-normal">next normal</a>”—what the world may look like after strong virus-control measures are lifted. The measures in place are expected to lead to the largest quarterly decline in economic activity since World War II. An unprecedented 40 to 50 percent decline in discretionary spending will translate to a roughly 8 to 13 percent drop in GDP. (For our macroeconomic scenarios and latest insights, see <a href="/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis">McKinsey.com/coronavirus</a>.) While many CPG companies have withstood the initial economic shock, all will need to prepare for the longer-lasting effects, including an erosion in consumer confidence that will drive recessionary behavior.</p>
<p>In this article, we describe five trends in the consumer and retail landscape that have emerged during the crisis and, we believe, will persist in the aftermath. We then recommend the creation of a plan-ahead team to equip CPG companies for whatever the next normal may turn out to be.</p>

<p>We map four horizons of the crisis and beyond (Exhibit 1). At the time of this writing, most countries around the world—with notable exceptions in Asia—are still navigating the crisis. The questions many are now grappling with include: What will the next normal look like? And how long will the intervening period of partial restrictions last?</p>

<p>It’s increasingly clear that the intervening period will be lengthy. Consumers and retailers will need to adjust to ongoing physical distancing and travel restrictions. Outlets and venues where physical distancing cannot be achieved will be among the last to reopen.</p>
<p>Current sentiment, the trends we are seeing in Asia, and lessons from the last recession lead us to anticipate at least five behaviors to “stick” through the prolonged recovery and the next normal: increased price sensitivity, higher digital engagement, rise in attention to wellness and hygiene, “nesting” at home, and a redefinition of brand purpose. We also expect to see important channel shifts: a smaller food-service sector, retailer consolidation, the rise of value retailers, and Amazon’s growth in grocery (a sector in which the e-commerce giant has historically had lower share).</p>

<h3>Economic insecurity, leading to price sensitivity</h3>
<p>Already, two-thirds of consumers are pessimistic or unsure about the pandemic’s lasting effect (Exhibit 2). Despite their comparative optimism for economic recovery, 46 percent of US consumers and 28 percent of Chinese consumers said they plan to reduce spending in the coming weeks.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="fbe266e8-dacd-4bfa-99ef-59ad0ce52f31"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="fbe266e8-dacd-4bfa-99ef-59ad0ce52f31" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey Consumer Sentiment Survey in China and United States, March 30 to April 6, 2020.
    </span></span></span></a></span> (For our latest surveys, see “Global surveys of consumer sentiment during the coronavirus crisis.”)</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 2</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/consumer%20packaged%20goods/our%20insights/how%20consumer%20goods%20companies%20can%20prepare%20for%20the%20next%20normal/svgz-covid-consumergoods-ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="In most markets navigating the crisis, the majority of consumers are pessimistic or unsure about the economic recovery." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/consumer%20packaged%20goods/our%20insights/how%20consumer%20goods%20companies%20can%20prepare%20for%20the%20next%20normal/svgz-covid-consumergoods-ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. <p>The 2008 recession is an imperfect analog to the COVID-19 crisis—which is more of a shock, with many governments introducing bold, unprecedented fiscal measures—but we believe it offers valuable lessons about how consumers behave under financial stress. That recession had a lasting effect on consumer confidence, which didn’t return to prerecession levels until 2011 in Germany, 2014 in the United Kingdom and the United States, and 2017 in China.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="0389c1ab-fa6c-40db-a6e8-519a6682ae6c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="0389c1ab-fa6c-40db-a6e8-519a6682ae6c" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Consumer Confidence Index, OECD, oecd-ilibrary.org.</span></span></span></a></span> Consumers reduced their spending in several ways:</p>
<ul>
    <li><em>Refocusing on home occasions.</em> Many consumers spent less outside the home; 55 percent of Germans and 63 percent of Americans said they ate out less.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="9ce7daee-e3b0-43f1-83eb-f39622ff3f7d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="9ce7daee-e3b0-43f1-83eb-f39622ff3f7d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey US Consumer Sentiment Survey, February 2009; McKinsey Global Institute Europe Consumer Insights Survey, December 2008.</span></span></span></a></span></li>
    <li><em>Cutting back on nonessentials.</em> Two-thirds of US shoppers said they cut back on high-end luxury goods; one-third cut back on cosmetics.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="560e397f-6bd5-42b9-95c6-bfeebc6a6273"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="560e397f-6bd5-42b9-95c6-bfeebc6a6273" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey US Consumer Sentiment Survey, February 2009.</span></span></span></a></span></li>
    <li><em>Deal seeking.</em> Shoppers became increasingly promotion conscious. In the United Kingdom, the percentage of products sold on discount climbed from 26 percent in 2002–06 to 36 percent in 2011.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="319c4836-168c-487c-866d-58fb405c5ce9"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="319c4836-168c-487c-866d-58fb405c5ce9" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>State of the nation 2012: A review of UK consumers and the grocery industry in 2011</em>, Nielsen, 2012; National Consumer Panel data on total purchasing.</span></span></span></a></span></li>
    <li><em>Trading down.</em> Consumers switched to cheaper brands or private labels. UK private-label sales increased by 10 percentage points from 2008 to 2010.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="672df669-d000-418f-8adc-697054f0a066"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="672df669-d000-418f-8adc-697054f0a066" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Euromonitor International data from 2008 to 2010.</span></span></span></a></span></li>
    <li><em>Shifting channels.</em> Many consumers began shopping at value retailers. Discounters now account for 10 percent of grocery sales in the UK market, up from 3 percent in 2006.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="67831e0f-f4a9-4c7e-bd45-7385782f9a76"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">7</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="67831e0f-f4a9-4c7e-bd45-7385782f9a76" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Euromonitor International data from 2006 to 2018.</span></span></span></a></span></li>
</ul>
<h3>A seismic shift in digital engagement</h3>
<p>Physical-distancing rules have increased consumption of online media and significantly accelerated e-commerce, particularly in markets that already had a head start. In the United Kingdom, for example, where online’s share of grocery shopping was 7 percent before the crisis, grocers are furiously increasing capacity to meet demand: the three largest grocers have added more than 500,000 new delivery slots—an increase of more than 30 percent.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="2fb3285a-dce7-4eb9-bfa3-2f44bbe4dae6"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">8</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="2fb3285a-dce7-4eb9-bfa3-2f44bbe4dae6" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Globaldata 2019 Food & Grocery; press searches.</span></span></span></a></span> For many discretionary categories, e-commerce has become <em>the</em> channel as stores have closed.</p>
<p>We expect this channel shift to endure to some extent, especially in countries where retailers had enough preexisting capability to offer a positive online experience. Early lessons from China suggest that three to six percentage points of online market share will be “sticky,”<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="2b494a80-26e2-467a-bbcd-335d3c987142"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">9</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="2b494a80-26e2-467a-bbcd-335d3c987142" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey Consumer Sentiment Survey in China (mobile), February 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> driven by older generations newly comfortable with digital channels and by new consumer segments who have overcome barriers to trial (such as account setup). Also, in the medium term, we expect shoppers to prefer the “safe” experience of shopping online to the prospect of shopping in crowded stores.</p>
<p>Amazon is likely to build momentum in fresh food and packaged goods, especially in markets where the major grocers lack e-commerce “legs.” In the month leading up to March 14—even before governments issued shelter-in-place guidance—Amazon US saw year-on-year growth of 41 percent in household goods, 25 percent in health products, and 23 percent in groceries.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="49bae532-ab30-42d8-b3fe-c5cf4f47617a"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">10</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="49bae532-ab30-42d8-b3fe-c5cf4f47617a" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Stackline data from February 15 to March 14, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<h3>Rise in attention to wellness and hygiene</h3>
<p>The wellness trend has endured—and even gained strength—during the outbreak. “Healthy eating” has remained the highest priority of food shoppers across Europe: net sentiment (positive responses less negative) was 55 percent, rising to 82 percent in Italy.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="68b141ac-92a2-4260-95df-28fb80c5b412"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">11</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="68b141ac-92a2-4260-95df-28fb80c5b412" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey Consumer Sentiment Survey in France, Germany, Italy, Spain, and United Kingdom, March 27 to March 29, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> Consumers are also investing in at-home exercise: in Germany and the United Kingdom, Amazon’s fitness-equipment sales spiked by approximately 60 percent each week in March.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="607ba474-88b5-4bfc-95d4-fbdfb7915538"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">12</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="607ba474-88b5-4bfc-95d4-fbdfb7915538" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Stackline data for month leading up to March 28, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>We expect this upward trajectory to continue into the next normal. Hygiene will become a core element of wellness. The speed of the virus’s spread has highlighted the level of connectedness in society—and the associated risk. Brands should consider the implications for their strategy and communications (for instance, reassessing manufacturing processes and packaging, as well as emphasizing health and cleanliness in marketing messages). The battle to eradicate COVID-19 will be a long one, and CPG manufacturers will need to prove their safety and trust credentials.</p>
<h3>Nesting at home</h3>
<p>Staying in is the new going out. Once restrictions are lifted, we expect consumers to continue spending more time at home, driven by a desire to save money, persistent safety concerns, and a newfound pleasure in nesting. Through the crisis period, many have invested in upgrading their homes and gardens or bought equipment for new hobbies and routines. Next to groceries, the category that saw the highest growth in US e-commerce in recent weeks has been breadmakers (652 percent growth). Other nonessentials, such as weight-training gear (307 percent), computer monitors (179 percent), and craft kits (117 percent) also made the top-100 list.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c198e45f-133e-4dbb-b399-f1a6e6224446"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">13</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c198e45f-133e-4dbb-b399-f1a6e6224446" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Stackline data on United States for March 2020 versus March 2019.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<h3>Redefinition of purpose</h3>
<p>Large CPG companies have prioritized crisis-related communications (such as announcements of new safety protocols and charitable donations). Digital-native brands have nimbly connected with their social-media communities about how they’re helping people affected by COVID-19. Consumers may expect companies to continue this heightened emphasis on social responsibility after the crisis ends. In the previous recession, more than 75 percent of consumers agreed that “corporations should operate in a way that aligns with society’s interests, even if that means sacrificing shareholder value.”<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="66e6e59f-310b-4c5d-ad0f-f97ee4aadaf4"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">14</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="66e6e59f-310b-4c5d-ad0f-f97ee4aadaf4" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">2011 Edelman Trust Barometer, Daniel J. Edelman Holdings, August 30, 2011, edelman.com.
    </span></span></span></a></span> That said, brands must be careful to strike the right tone. During this pandemic, 77 percent of consumers said they appreciate CPG companies communicating how their brands can be helpful in daily life, but an almost equal percentage said brands shouldn’t “exploit” COVID-19 as a commercial opportunity.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="6d2d1ac8-65bc-42fa-b1fd-3cb8a0171984"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">15</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="6d2d1ac8-65bc-42fa-b1fd-3cb8a0171984" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Brands in a pandemic world: Insights from Kantar’s COVID-19 Barometer,” WARC, March 27, 2020, warc.com.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>It will be essential for companies to balance existing focus areas with emerging consumer concerns. Sustainability, for instance, continues to be important to consumers in many markets (60 percent of UK consumers cited it as a top consideration when food shopping).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="146dd56e-d9ed-4973-ad28-7e557aa56978"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">16</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="146dd56e-d9ed-4973-ad28-7e557aa56978" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey UK Consumer Survey 2020 (part of <em>The Rise of Conscious Eating</em>, forthcoming summer 2020).</span></span></span></a></span> Yet consumers who have become more price sensitive or more concerned about hygiene may favor single-use packaging.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ebf5e882-4168-422e-934a-16959facd9e2"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">17</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ebf5e882-4168-422e-934a-16959facd9e2" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Nielsen and McKinsey analysis of the last three weeks of March 2020 versus 2015–18.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<br>
<br>
<p>CPG companies should examine the potential impact of these trends on the categories in which they play. Besides these, we are also monitoring two other trends, whose longevity is less clear: deurbanization and big-brand growth. With cities becoming COVID-19 epicenters, urbanites may move to the suburbs, or cities could see a significant reduction in traffic as people stay local. Big brands may benefit over the longer term, as retailers’ current focus on high-volume SKUs will change the consumer decision set. (In the United States, for instance, large and midsize brands captured 60 percent of recent growth, compared with only 20 percent in previous years.)</p>
<h3>Channel shifts</h3>
<p>These consumer trends will have channel implications, each of which will have varying impact on different countries and categories. Most significantly, food-service operators—particularly independents—will experience substantial contraction and consolidation as a result of physical-distancing restrictions and the recessionary environment. Food-service closures have accounted for 10 to 20 percent grocery growth in Western markets; when the food-service sector reopens, we expect a few percentage points to remain in grocery.</p>
<p>We also expect to see significant retailer consolidation, especially in sectors that were less well capitalized and struggling before the outbreak, such as small US quick-service restaurants. Some distributors will go out of business, creating route-to-market challenges for some CPG players, especially in the fragmented trade.</p>
<p>Amazon and other e-marketplaces were already growing by 25 percent a year from 2013 to 2018<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="2f5e87fd-eeb0-4081-a75e-cca69a784522"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">18</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="2f5e87fd-eeb0-4081-a75e-cca69a784522" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Data for 2013 to 2018 from analyst reports, Euromonitor International, Kantar, Planet Retail, and S&P Capital IQ.</span></span></span></a></span>  but had previously struggled with the supply-chain complexity of fresh food and the economics of delivering CPG products. During the crisis, however, these players are likely to capture an outsize share of core grocery.</p>
<p>In offline grocery, discounters and other value retailers will benefit from the downturn, as they did in 2009. Major grocers will rationalize their assortments based on learnings during the crisis. They will also likely invest more in neighborhood proximity formats: in China, for instance, convenience-store sales were 8 percent higher in March than in January.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f051a82a-7dfd-45f2-9df7-6a532c878a8d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">19</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f051a82a-7dfd-45f2-9df7-6a532c878a8d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">MIYA payment data for the four weeks after March 8, 2020, versus the four weeks before January 29, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> And grocers will ask CPG companies for support in making the economics of e-commerce work.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="dark" data-module-background="deep-blue" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="top-right" class="mck-o-edge-to-edge SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header___N7qG mck-c-module-wrapper"><style></style><div data-component="mdc-c-background-image" class="mdc-c-bg-image___GJdv1_990311c background-image-section-header-57553500DB06437280732A0967D610CD-bg SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__parallax-container__sgMMy" role="img" aria-label="Getting ahead of the next phase" style="transform: translate(0px, 0px);"></div><div class="mdc-c-bg-image___GJdv1_990311c mdc-c-bg-image--opaque-bg___CauU1_990311c" style="opacity:0.3"></div><div class="mck-o-container"><div class="mck-o-container--wrapped mck-o-container--mobile-spacing"><div id="section-header-2" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__wrapper__CZEyB"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-12 SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__wrapper-positioned__fIWpF"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-sm SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__wrapper-text__hSx1f" style="display: none; opacity: 0;"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__heading__2ePOu"><span>Getting ahead of the next phase</span></h2></div><div class="SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__section-holder__BaLti"></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>By now, most CPG companies have well-established crisis-response teams monitoring the situation and reacting accordingly. Preparing for the next normal, however, calls for a distinct working group: a plan-ahead team tasked with planning across multiple time horizons. As our colleagues explain in a recent article, “<a href="/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/getting-ahead-of-the-next-stage-of-the-coronavirus-crisis">Getting ahead of the next stage of the coronavirus crisis</a>,” the plan-ahead team should work through five frames: a realistic starting position, scenarios, a broad direction of travel, strategic moves, and trigger points. In the remainder of this article, we discuss CPG-specific considerations for each of these frames.</p>
<h3>1. Gain a realistic view of your starting position</h3>
<p>The plan-ahead team should review the company’s financial assumptions, ongoing initiatives, and strategic choices, and sort them into three buckets: “still about right,” “wrong,” and “unsure.” CPG companies should reevaluate their 2020 growth expectations and key drivers, including the markets, categories, and customers that will deliver growth; the role of planned product launches and campaigns in light of store closures and recessionary pressure; and the allocation of resources, including talent. This exercise will clarify your starting point and provide a clear picture of the challenges you need to address.</p>
<h3>2. Develop scenarios for multiple versions of your future</h3>
<p>Scenario planning for the next normal is a daunting task, with many macroeconomic possibilities, vast differences in markets (and even regions or cities), and only an early view of the consumption implications. “Bound the uncertainty” by considering at least four discrete scenarios—each covering country, category, and channel outcomes—underpinned by clearly stated assumptions about containment measures and financial aid.</p>
<h3>3. Establish your posture and broad direction of travel</h3>
<p>After a detailed scenario-planning exercise, it may seem odd to make macro choices—but they help to align companies on the direction of travel. CPG companies might consider their stances on the following:</p>
<ul>
    <li><em>Global business.</em> Will you focus on your previous priority growth markets or review your segmentation based on new behaviors and economic outlook?</li>
    <li><em>Portfolio.</em> Will you continue to prioritize at-home essentials or invest in rebuilding demand for products that consumers largely held off buying?</li>
    <li><em>Value proposition.</em> Will you reposition premium offerings or prioritize cheaper brands? </li>
    <li><em>Discretionary categories.</em> Is your primary aim to restart operations and manage your bottom line, or will you invest—for example, in marketing or direct to consumer (DTC)—to capture share?</li>
    <li><em>Essential categories.</em> Will you focus on traditional retail partners or on growth channels, such as e-marketplaces?</li>
    <li><em>Challenger brands.</em> Will you wait to bounce back or create a marketing and promotional growth plan?</li>
</ul>
<p>Think about how to align your operating model with these stances and about which new “muscles” you might have to build. Establishing your posture and broad direction of travel will help you decide on strategic moves.</p>
<h3>4. Determine actions and strategic moves that are robust across scenarios</h3>
<p>The plan-ahead team can then draft and pressure-test action plans for each scenario. CPG players have a range of commercial, operational, and strategic areas to cover.</p>
<h4>Accelerate e-commerce and digital marketing</h4>
<p>The specific actions will depend partly on your posture and business model, but all CPG companies should deepen their relationships with third-party e-commerce partners and work with them in new ways, such as category captaincy, deeper data exchange, or shared warehousing. At the same time, avoid overreliance on the e-marketplace giants—strengthen your relationships with second-tier e-tailers and owned e-commerce (such as DTC websites, owned marketplaces or ecosystems, or partnerships in which you control your brand presence and own the consumer relationships and data.)</p>
<p>With customer decision journeys encompassing more digital touchpoints and increasing in complexity, shoppers will expect CPG companies to have a consistent presence online and offline. Capturing and managing data will be essential and can help deliver precision marketing at lower cost. Finally, despite the uncertainty, consider actively recruiting otherwise hard-to-come-by digital talent.</p>
<h4>Revisit your channel strategy and customer segmentation</h4>
<p>In light of the aforementioned retail dynamics, reset your channel strategy around both the enduring global trends and smaller, local shifts. This will in turn require a review of your customer-segmentation strategy and growth targets, and an understanding of the capabilities you may need for new partnerships. Rebase overall investment across tiers as needed and build up new priority customers with stronger ways-of-working agreements. Decide how you’ll manage the trade spend you’d previously allocated to now-lower-priority customers, while maintaining those relationships and your fair share of sales. Also, decide how you’ll support the return of food service, if it’s important to your mix—especially in the difficult period immediately after lockdowns are lifted.</p>
<h4>Revise assortment and pricing</h4>
<p>After the crisis, retailers are likely to want to reevaluate their category vision and assortment, which could be good news for CPG companies that play in multiple categories and price tiers. To prepare action plans, know your category consumer better than anyone else: test ranging and new promotional mechanics, revisit insights from the previous recession, and, later, supplement in-store learnings with primary consumer and shopper research to understand postcrisis perspectives.</p>
<p>Reprioritize your portfolio based on shifts in consumer and customer needs and on changes in sourcing and the supply chain. And get granular: one size will not fit all. Build shopper-, occasion-, channel-, and customer-specific plans.</p>
<h4>Strengthen your purpose orientation</h4>
<p>A company’s actions during times of crisis are written into its history and make a lasting impression on consumers. To <a href="/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/demonstrating-corporate-purpose-in-the-time-of-coronavirus">lead with purpose</a>, understand your stakeholders’ needs and review the trade-offs in addressing them. Think about how to bring your greatest strength or “superpower” to bear, perhaps more creatively than before.</p>
<p>Communicate frequently and clearly, but you don’t need to have all the answers—you can crowdsource ideas and involve your employees. Your jointly created purpose can then be a source of energy and renewal. Finally, use purpose as a filter for your action plans. If they don’t stack up against your values, identity, and legacy, look for alternatives.</p>
<h4>Build a resilient supply chain</h4>
<p>While the immediate need during this crisis is an operational supply chain, the next focus will be to build a smarter, more flexible, and, especially, more resilient one. Heads of operations and CIOs should review the strategy, footprint, assets, processes, and tools along the entire supply chain. They will have to decide whether efficiency and centralized footprints remain the answer to manage future risk. They will also need to determine whether legacy infrastructure and systems should be upgraded to autonomous end-to-end planning systems or to a combination of advanced analytics and end-to-end visualization solutions, for better complexity management.</p>
<p>Embed new ways of working based on lessons from the crisis. Complement monthly sales and operations planning (S&OP) cycles with weekly control towers, which help balance service, cost, and cash (that is, inventory). Last year’s sales and traditional forecasts will be less valuable, so dial up planning across sales and operations and jointly make decisions about demand—for example, is a huge order a true uptick in demand, a one-time effect of new ranging, or the same demand pulled forward a week? For priority customers, short-term solutions (such as connected inventory or simplified routes from factory to store) could be leveraged on a more regular basis to manage new demand levels.</p>
<h4>Define the next level of productivity</h4>
<p>Any short- to medium-term falloff in spending (resulting, for example, from store closures and travel restrictions) should be swept into updated budgets. Rigorously allocate all remaining funds toward the highest-ROI activities. Steer demand to customers and brands with excess supply, and functional capacity to more urgent needs.</p>
<p>Given COVID-19’s immediate impact, planning for the next normal can feel like a real-time zero-based-budgeting effort. Analyze performance at the lower spend levels and then build back investment in priority categories, brands, and channels, with monthly monitoring of triggers to start “investment spend” as you emerge from the crisis. In the 2008 downturn, the top 20 percent of performers reduced costs more quickly and were faster to invest as the economy recovered.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="35767177-298c-41ea-a2a1-be9729dcb3f9"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">20</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="35767177-298c-41ea-a2a1-be9729dcb3f9" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"> S&P Capital IQ and Corporate Performance Analytics by McKinsey data; performers defined as those in top quintile based on total returns to shareholders from 2007 to 2011.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Accelerate the role of digitization and automation in supply chain, back-office functions, procurement, and even route to market. Done right, automation transformations can have an impact on both the top and bottom lines in as little as three months.</p>
<h4>Stay abreast of regulatory changes</h4>
<p>Pay close attention to government mandates and regulatory actions, which may become more interventionist in areas such as consumer health, control over national or local food ecosystems, and employee safety. If you lack an experienced public-affairs department, consider temporarily devoting resources to government relations and making it part of the crisis-response team’s remit.</p>
<h4>Scan for small-brand M&A</h4>
<p>Consider updating your M&A strategy in the context of your posture—for example, buying rather than building new capabilities or reframing priorities (for example, resilience over pure efficiency). If you decide to look for complementary assets, focus on <a href="/industries/consumer-packaged-goods/our-insights/the-next-wave-of-consumer-m-and-a-executing-for-value">strategic acquisitions</a>: brands that expand your portfolio, challengers within your major categories, or resilient adjacent players.</p>
<p>While industry players are balancing many challenges, private-equity firms are single-mindedly focused on preparing for transactions. Make sure that any asset-valuation work is risk-managed and rooted in your scenarios. Also, consider divestments of your own underperforming or less-strategic assets to free up cash and ensure longer-term resilience.</p>
<h3>5. Set trigger points that drive your organization to act at the right time</h3>
<p>Finally, time is of the essence. Lay out key indicators and set clear trigger points for each scenario; ensure that your teams have the data and processes to identify these trigger points as soon as possible. It’s then up to the top team to give the go-ahead to execute the plans.</p>
<hr>
<p>The consumer trends that are crystallizing during the crisis and will most likely persist—recessionary behavior, greater digital engagement, attention to wellness and hygiene, nesting, and heightened expectations of corporate purpose—will affect every CPG category. By establishing plan-ahead teams and acting on the five frames, CPG companies can emerge stronger from the crisis and be well positioned to succeed in the next normal.</p></div><div class="container-placeholder"></div></div></div><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xl"><section role="contentinfo" data-layer-region="article-about-authors" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 AboutAuthor_mck-c-about-author__nRJzu"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><h5 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c mdc-u-align-center">About the author(s)</h5><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline mck-u-links-inline--secondary mdc-u-mt-5"><div><p><strong><a href="/sitecore/service/notfound.aspx?item=web%3a%7bd35432e1-c3fa-4249-a566-da94823dc091%7d%40en">Raphael Buck</a></strong> is a senior partner in McKinsey’s Zurich office; <strong><a href="/our-people/tracy-francis">Tracy Francis</a></strong> is a senior partner in the São Paulo office; <strong>Eldon Little</strong> is a senior partner in the Dallas office; and <strong><a href="/our-people/jessica-moulton">Jessica Moulton</a></strong> is a senior partner in the London office, where <strong>Samantha Phillips</strong> is an associate partner. </p>

CPG leaders have focused on meeting this demand while guarding the safety of employees and customers.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAt the same time, forward-thinking CPG companies have begun to think about the \u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/beyond-coronavirus-the-path-to-the-next-normal\"\u003enext normal\u003c/a\u003e\u0026rdquo;\u0026mdash;what the world may look like after strong virus-control measures are lifted. The measures in place are expected to lead to the largest quarterly decline in economic activity since World War II. An unprecedented 40 to 50 percent decline in discretionary spending will translate to a roughly 8 to 13 percent drop in GDP. (For our macroeconomic scenarios and latest insights, see \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis\"\u003eMcKinsey.com/coronavirus\u003c/a\u003e.) While many CPG companies have withstood the initial economic shock, all will need to prepare for the longer-lasting effects, including an erosion in consumer confidence that will drive recessionary behavior.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn this article, we describe five trends in the consumer and retail landscape that have emerged during the crisis and, we believe, will persist in the aftermath. We then recommend the creation of a plan-ahead team to equip CPG companies for whatever the next normal may turn out to be.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[SectionHeader 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eWe map four horizons of the crisis and beyond (Exhibit 1). At the time of this writing, most countries around the world\u0026mdash;with notable exceptions in Asia\u0026mdash;are still navigating the crisis. The questions many are now grappling with include: What will the next normal look like? And how long will the intervening period of partial restrictions last?\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eIt\u0026rsquo;s increasingly clear that the intervening period will be lengthy. Consumers and retailers will need to adjust to ongoing physical distancing and travel restrictions. Outlets and venues where physical distancing cannot be achieved will be among the last to reopen.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCurrent sentiment, the trends we are seeing in Asia, and lessons from the last recession lead us to anticipate at least five behaviors to \u0026ldquo;stick\u0026rdquo; through the prolonged recovery and the next normal: increased price sensitivity, higher digital engagement, rise in attention to wellness and hygiene, \u0026ldquo;nesting\u0026rdquo; at home, and a redefinition of brand purpose. We also expect to see important channel shifts: a smaller food-service sector, retailer consolidation, the rise of value retailers, and Amazon\u0026rsquo;s growth in grocery (a sector in which the e-commerce giant has historically had lower share).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Ceros covid]]\n\u003ch3\u003eEconomic insecurity, leading to price sensitivity\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlready, two-thirds of consumers are pessimistic or unsure about the pandemic\u0026rsquo;s lasting effect (Exhibit 2). Despite their comparative optimism for economic recovery, 46 percent of US consumers and 28 percent of Chinese consumers said they plan to reduce spending in the coming weeks.[[footnote 1]] (For our latest surveys, see \u0026ldquo;Global surveys of consumer sentiment during the coronavirus crisis.\u0026rdquo;)\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 2]]\n\u003cp\u003eThe 2008 recession is an imperfect analog to the COVID-19 crisis\u0026mdash;which is more of a shock, with many governments introducing bold, unprecedented fiscal measures\u0026mdash;but we believe it offers valuable lessons about how consumers behave under financial stress. That recession had a lasting effect on consumer confidence, which didn\u0026rsquo;t return to prerecession levels until 2011 in Germany, 2014 in the United Kingdom and the United States, and 2017 in China.[[footnote 2]] Consumers reduced their spending in several ways:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eRefocusing on home occasions.\u003c/em\u003e Many consumers spent less outside the home; 55 percent of Germans and 63 percent of Americans said they ate out less.[[footnote 3]]\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eCutting back on nonessentials.\u003c/em\u003e Two-thirds of US shoppers said they cut back on high-end luxury goods; one-third cut back on cosmetics.[[footnote 4]]\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eDeal seeking.\u003c/em\u003e Shoppers became increasingly promotion conscious. In the United Kingdom, the percentage of products sold on discount climbed from 26 percent in 2002\u0026ndash;06 to 36 percent in 2011.[[footnote 5]]\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eTrading down.\u003c/em\u003e Consumers switched to cheaper brands or private labels. UK private-label sales increased by 10 percentage points from 2008 to 2010.[[footnote 6]]\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eShifting channels.\u003c/em\u003e Many consumers began shopping at value retailers. Discounters now account for 10 percent of grocery sales in the UK market, up from 3 percent in 2006.[[footnote 7]]\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eA seismic shift in digital engagement\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePhysical-distancing rules have increased consumption of online media and significantly accelerated e-commerce, particularly in markets that already had a head start. In the United Kingdom, for example, where online\u0026rsquo;s share of grocery shopping was 7 percent before the crisis, grocers are furiously increasing capacity to meet demand: the three largest grocers have added more than 500,000 new delivery slots\u0026mdash;an increase of more than 30 percent.[[footnote 8]] For many discretionary categories, e-commerce has become \u003cem\u003ethe\u003c/em\u003e channel as stores have closed.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe expect this channel shift to endure to some extent, especially in countries where retailers had enough preexisting capability to offer a positive online experience. Early lessons from China suggest that three to six percentage points of online market share will be \u0026ldquo;sticky,\u0026rdquo;[[footnote 9]] driven by older generations newly comfortable with digital channels and by new consumer segments who have overcome barriers to trial (such as account setup). Also, in the medium term, we expect shoppers to prefer the \u0026ldquo;safe\u0026rdquo; experience of shopping online to the prospect of shopping in crowded stores.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAmazon is likely to build momentum in fresh food and packaged goods, especially in markets where the major grocers lack e-commerce \u0026ldquo;legs.\u0026rdquo; In the month leading up to March 14\u0026mdash;even before governments issued shelter-in-place guidance\u0026mdash;Amazon US saw year-on-year growth of 41 percent in household goods, 25 percent in health products, and 23 percent in groceries.[[footnote 10]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eRise in attention to wellness and hygiene\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe wellness trend has endured\u0026mdash;and even gained strength\u0026mdash;during the outbreak. \u0026ldquo;Healthy eating\u0026rdquo; has remained the highest priority of food shoppers across Europe: net sentiment (positive responses less negative) was 55 percent, rising to 82 percent in Italy.[[footnote 11]] Consumers are also investing in at-home exercise: in Germany and the United Kingdom, Amazon\u0026rsquo;s fitness-equipment sales spiked by approximately 60 percent each week in March.[[footnote 12]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe expect this upward trajectory to continue into the next normal. Hygiene will become a core element of wellness. The speed of the virus\u0026rsquo;s spread has highlighted the level of connectedness in society\u0026mdash;and the associated risk. Brands should consider the implications for their strategy and communications (for instance, reassessing manufacturing processes and packaging, as well as emphasizing health and cleanliness in marketing messages). The battle to eradicate COVID-19 will be a long one, and CPG manufacturers will need to prove their safety and trust credentials.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eNesting at home\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eStaying in is the new going out. Once restrictions are lifted, we expect consumers to continue spending more time at home, driven by a desire to save money, persistent safety concerns, and a newfound pleasure in nesting. Through the crisis period, many have invested in upgrading their homes and gardens or bought equipment for new hobbies and routines. Next to groceries, the category that saw the highest growth in US e-commerce in recent weeks has been breadmakers (652 percent growth). Other nonessentials, such as weight-training gear (307 percent), computer monitors (179 percent), and craft kits (117 percent) also made the top-100 list.[[footnote 13]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eRedefinition of purpose\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLarge CPG companies have prioritized crisis-related communications (such as announcements of new safety protocols and charitable donations). Digital-native brands have nimbly connected with their social-media communities about how they\u0026rsquo;re helping people affected by COVID-19. Consumers may expect companies to continue this heightened emphasis on social responsibility after the crisis ends. In the previous recession, more than 75 percent of consumers agreed that \u0026ldquo;corporations should operate in a way that aligns with society\u0026rsquo;s interests, even if that means sacrificing shareholder value.\u0026rdquo;[[footnote 14]] That said, brands must be careful to strike the right tone. During this pandemic, 77 percent of consumers said they appreciate CPG companies communicating how their brands can be helpful in daily life, but an almost equal percentage said brands shouldn\u0026rsquo;t \u0026ldquo;exploit\u0026rdquo; COVID-19 as a commercial opportunity.[[footnote 15]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt will be essential for companies to balance existing focus areas with emerging consumer concerns. Sustainability, for instance, continues to be important to consumers in many markets (60 percent of UK consumers cited it as a top consideration when food shopping).[[footnote 16]] Yet consumers who have become more price sensitive or more concerned about hygiene may favor single-use packaging.[[footnote 17]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCPG companies should examine the potential impact of these trends on the categories in which they play. Besides these, we are also monitoring two other trends, whose longevity is less clear: deurbanization and big-brand growth. With cities becoming COVID-19 epicenters, urbanites may move to the suburbs, or cities could see a significant reduction in traffic as people stay local. Big brands may benefit over the longer term, as retailers\u0026rsquo; current focus on high-volume SKUs will change the consumer decision set. (In the United States, for instance, large and midsize brands captured 60 percent of recent growth, compared with only 20 percent in previous years.)\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eChannel shifts\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThese consumer trends will have channel implications, each of which will have varying impact on different countries and categories. Most significantly, food-service operators\u0026mdash;particularly independents\u0026mdash;will experience substantial contraction and consolidation as a result of physical-distancing restrictions and the recessionary environment. Food-service closures have accounted for 10 to 20 percent grocery growth in Western markets; when the food-service sector reopens, we expect a few percentage points to remain in grocery.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe also expect to see significant retailer consolidation, especially in sectors that were less well capitalized and struggling before the outbreak, such as small US quick-service restaurants. Some distributors will go out of business, creating route-to-market challenges for some CPG players, especially in the fragmented trade.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAmazon and other e-marketplaces were already growing by 25 percent a year from 2013 to 2018[[footnote 18]]  but had previously struggled with the supply-chain complexity of fresh food and the economics of delivering CPG products. During the crisis, however, these players are likely to capture an outsize share of core grocery.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn offline grocery, discounters and other value retailers will benefit from the downturn, as they did in 2009. Major grocers will rationalize their assortments based on learnings during the crisis. They will also likely invest more in neighborhood proximity formats: in China, for instance, convenience-store sales were 8 percent higher in March than in January.[[footnote 19]] And grocers will ask CPG companies for support in making the economics of e-commerce work.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[SectionHeader 2]]\n\u003cp\u003eBy now, most CPG companies have well-established crisis-response teams monitoring the situation and reacting accordingly. Preparing for the next normal, however, calls for a distinct working group: a plan-ahead team tasked with planning across multiple time horizons. As our colleagues explain in a recent article, \u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/getting-ahead-of-the-next-stage-of-the-coronavirus-crisis\"\u003eGetting ahead of the next stage of the coronavirus crisis\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026rdquo; the plan-ahead team should work through five frames: a realistic starting position, scenarios, a broad direction of travel, strategic moves, and trigger points. In the remainder of this article, we discuss CPG-specific considerations for each of these frames.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e1. Gain a realistic view of your starting position\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe plan-ahead team should review the company\u0026rsquo;s financial assumptions, ongoing initiatives, and strategic choices, and sort them into three buckets: \u0026ldquo;still about right,\u0026rdquo; \u0026ldquo;wrong,\u0026rdquo; and \u0026ldquo;unsure.\u0026rdquo; CPG companies should reevaluate their 2020 growth expectations and key drivers, including the markets, categories, and customers that will deliver growth; the role of planned product launches and campaigns in light of store closures and recessionary pressure; and the allocation of resources, including talent. This exercise will clarify your starting point and provide a clear picture of the challenges you need to address.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e2. Develop scenarios for multiple versions of your future\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eScenario planning for the next normal is a daunting task, with many macroeconomic possibilities, vast differences in markets (and even regions or cities), and only an early view of the consumption implications. \u0026ldquo;Bound the uncertainty\u0026rdquo; by considering at least four discrete scenarios\u0026mdash;each covering country, category, and channel outcomes\u0026mdash;underpinned by clearly stated assumptions about containment measures and financial aid.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e3. Establish your posture and broad direction of travel\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAfter a detailed scenario-planning exercise, it may seem odd to make macro choices\u0026mdash;but they help to align companies on the direction of travel. CPG companies might consider their stances on the following:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eGlobal business.\u003c/em\u003e Will you focus on your previous priority growth markets or review your segmentation based on new behaviors and economic outlook?\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003ePortfolio.\u003c/em\u003e Will you continue to prioritize at-home essentials or invest in rebuilding demand for products that consumers largely held off buying?\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eValue proposition.\u003c/em\u003e Will you reposition premium offerings or prioritize cheaper brands? \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eDiscretionary categories.\u003c/em\u003e Is your primary aim to restart operations and manage your bottom line, or will you invest\u0026mdash;for example, in marketing or direct to consumer (DTC)\u0026mdash;to capture share?\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eEssential categories.\u003c/em\u003e Will you focus on traditional retail partners or on growth channels, such as e-marketplaces?\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eChallenger brands.\u003c/em\u003e Will you wait to bounce back or create a marketing and promotional growth plan?\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThink about how to align your operating model with these stances and about which new \u0026ldquo;muscles\u0026rdquo; you might have to build. Establishing your posture and broad direction of travel will help you decide on strategic moves.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e4. Determine actions and strategic moves that are robust across scenarios\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe plan-ahead team can then draft and pressure-test action plans for each scenario. CPG players have a range of commercial, operational, and strategic areas to cover.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eAccelerate e-commerce and digital marketing\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe specific actions will depend partly on your posture and business model, but all CPG companies should deepen their relationships with third-party e-commerce partners and work with them in new ways, such as category captaincy, deeper data exchange, or shared warehousing. At the same time, avoid overreliance on the e-marketplace giants\u0026mdash;strengthen your relationships with second-tier e-tailers and owned e-commerce (such as DTC websites, owned marketplaces or ecosystems, or partnerships in which you control your brand presence and own the consumer relationships and data.)\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWith customer decision journeys encompassing more digital touchpoints and increasing in complexity, shoppers will expect CPG companies to have a consistent presence online and offline. Capturing and managing data will be essential and can help deliver precision marketing at lower cost. Finally, despite the uncertainty, consider actively recruiting otherwise hard-to-come-by digital talent.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eRevisit your channel strategy and customer segmentation\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn light of the aforementioned retail dynamics, reset your channel strategy around both the enduring global trends and smaller, local shifts. This will in turn require a review of your customer-segmentation strategy and growth targets, and an understanding of the capabilities you may need for new partnerships. Rebase overall investment across tiers as needed and build up new priority customers with stronger ways-of-working agreements. Decide how you\u0026rsquo;ll manage the trade spend you\u0026rsquo;d previously allocated to now-lower-priority customers, while maintaining those relationships and your fair share of sales. Also, decide how you\u0026rsquo;ll support the return of food service, if it\u0026rsquo;s important to your mix\u0026mdash;especially in the difficult period immediately after lockdowns are lifted.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eRevise assortment and pricing\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAfter the crisis, retailers are likely to want to reevaluate their category vision and assortment, which could be good news for CPG companies that play in multiple categories and price tiers. To prepare action plans, know your category consumer better than anyone else: test ranging and new promotional mechanics, revisit insights from the previous recession, and, later, supplement in-store learnings with primary consumer and shopper research to understand postcrisis perspectives.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eReprioritize your portfolio based on shifts in consumer and customer needs and on changes in sourcing and the supply chain. And get granular: one size will not fit all. Build shopper-, occasion-, channel-, and customer-specific plans.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eStrengthen your purpose orientation\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA company\u0026rsquo;s actions during times of crisis are written into its history and make a lasting impression on consumers. To \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/demonstrating-corporate-purpose-in-the-time-of-coronavirus\"\u003elead with purpose\u003c/a\u003e, understand your stakeholders\u0026rsquo; needs and review the trade-offs in addressing them. Think about how to bring your greatest strength or \u0026ldquo;superpower\u0026rdquo; to bear, perhaps more creatively than before.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCommunicate frequently and clearly, but you don\u0026rsquo;t need to have all the answers\u0026mdash;you can crowdsource ideas and involve your employees. Your jointly created purpose can then be a source of energy and renewal. Finally, use purpose as a filter for your action plans. If they don\u0026rsquo;t stack up against your values, identity, and legacy, look for alternatives.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eBuild a resilient supply chain\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhile the immediate need during this crisis is an operational supply chain, the next focus will be to build a smarter, more flexible, and, especially, more resilient one. Heads of operations and CIOs should review the strategy, footprint, assets, processes, and tools along the entire supply chain. They will have to decide whether efficiency and centralized footprints remain the answer to manage future risk. They will also need to determine whether legacy infrastructure and systems should be upgraded to autonomous end-to-end planning systems or to a combination of advanced analytics and end-to-end visualization solutions, for better complexity management.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEmbed new ways of working based on lessons from the crisis. Complement monthly sales and operations planning (S\u0026amp;OP) cycles with weekly control towers, which help balance service, cost, and cash (that is, inventory). Last year\u0026rsquo;s sales and traditional forecasts will be less valuable, so dial up planning across sales and operations and jointly make decisions about demand\u0026mdash;for example, is a huge order a true uptick in demand, a one-time effect of new ranging, or the same demand pulled forward a week? For priority customers, short-term solutions (such as connected inventory or simplified routes from factory to store) could be leveraged on a more regular basis to manage new demand levels.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eDefine the next level of productivity\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAny short- to medium-term falloff in spending (resulting, for example, from store closures and travel restrictions) should be swept into updated budgets. Rigorously allocate all remaining funds toward the highest-ROI activities. Steer demand to customers and brands with excess supply, and functional capacity to more urgent needs.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGiven COVID-19\u0026rsquo;s immediate impact, planning for the next normal can feel like a real-time zero-based-budgeting effort. Analyze performance at the lower spend levels and then build back investment in priority categories, brands, and channels, with monthly monitoring of triggers to start \u0026ldquo;investment spend\u0026rdquo; as you emerge from the crisis. In the 2008 downturn, the top 20 percent of performers reduced costs more quickly and were faster to invest as the economy recovered.[[footnote 20]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAccelerate the role of digitization and automation in supply chain, back-office functions, procurement, and even route to market. Done right, automation transformations can have an impact on both the top and bottom lines in as little as three months.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eStay abreast of regulatory changes\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePay close attention to government mandates and regulatory actions, which may become more interventionist in areas such as consumer health, control over national or local food ecosystems, and employee safety. If you lack an experienced public-affairs department, consider temporarily devoting resources to government relations and making it part of the crisis-response team\u0026rsquo;s remit.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eScan for small-brand M\u0026amp;A\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eConsider updating your M\u0026amp;A strategy in the context of your posture\u0026mdash;for example, buying rather than building new capabilities or reframing priorities (for example, resilience over pure efficiency). If you decide to look for complementary assets, focus on \u003ca href=\"/industries/consumer-packaged-goods/our-insights/the-next-wave-of-consumer-m-and-a-executing-for-value\"\u003estrategic acquisitions\u003c/a\u003e: brands that expand your portfolio, challengers within your major categories, or resilient adjacent players.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhile industry players are balancing many challenges, private-equity firms are single-mindedly focused on preparing for transactions. Make sure that any asset-valuation work is risk-managed and rooted in your scenarios. Also, consider divestments of your own underperforming or less-strategic assets to free up cash and ensure longer-term resilience.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e5. Set trigger points that drive your organization to act at the right time\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFinally, time is of the essence. Lay out key indicators and set clear trigger points for each scenario; ensure that your teams have the data and processes to identify these trigger points as soon as possible. It\u0026rsquo;s then up to the top team to give the go-ahead to execute the plans.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe consumer trends that are crystallizing during the crisis and will most likely persist\u0026mdash;recessionary behavior, greater digital engagement, attention to wellness and hygiene, nesting, and heightened expectations of corporate purpose\u0026mdash;will affect every CPG category.
